BE

United Rentals' cautious 2016 outlook impacted by 1) Energy/Industrial
concerns 2) Canadian FX headwind. Despite opaque macro, with minimal
Energy & Canada exposure, retain unchanged Ashtead PBT/EPS forecasts,
confident of continued share gain & cash generation. 1.3x FY18 net debt/
EBITDA gives flexibility for de-leveraging, increased dividends or buybacks.
Trading on 10.7x CY16E PE, Reaffirm Buy pre Ashtead 3Q16 results on March 1.

BE

United Rentals Q4: In-line Q4, but cautious outlook on Energy & Canadian FX headwinds:
Midpoint of URI guidance implies flat 2016 revenue & EBITDA Y/Y (3% below 2016 cons.) with
rental rates down 1% to 2% Y/Y. 2016 fleet capex reduced 22% to $1.2bn. Expect negative
stock price reaction pre 12am ET call

11:13 am
BE

Ashtead Read-Across: Ashtead differentiated from URI by minimal energy (2% Sunbelt
revs vs 10% for URI) and Canada (1% Sunbelt revs vs 10% for URI) exposure. Sunbelt focus on
1) smaller local customers, 2) high dollar utilization equipment, and 3) organic expansion
has led to Sunbelt growing rental revenues & profits faster than both United Rentals &
US rental market, delivering superior returns (ROCE/ROIC) whilst retaining more prudent
financial structure (sub 2x net debt/EBITDA).

BE

FCF Positive in FY17: Flexibility for Deleveraging & Capital Returns: Modelling flat
£1.1bn fleet capex in FY17-18, with bonus depreciation extension, Ashtead is FCF positive
in FY17, de-leveraging from 1.7x FY16 Net debt/EBITDA to 1.3x in FY18, giving flexibility for
increased dividends or share buybacks.

BE

Opaque Macro impacts Sentiment: With energy slowdown leading to easing US
industrial production, we appreciate market concerns regarding US construction outlook.
Our base case is US non-residential construction easing from 10% in 2015 to 5% in 2016,
reflected in (unchanged) Sunbelt rental revenue growth moderating from 22% in FY16E to
12% in FY17E & 8% in FY18E, with dollar utilization easing from 61% in FY14 to 51% in FY18E
(implicit time utilization/rental yield softness).
Unchanged Ashtead Estimates: With confidence in Ashtead trading, retain unchanged
FY16 estimates: £620m PBT/80.4p EPS, struck at $1.54/£, with each 1c boosting PBT by £5m.

11:14 am
BE

(@roddy1234: I'm an expert at finding spurious reasons to ban people.)

(he's kidding roddy)

11:15 am
BE

And ...... Stifel.

BE

Ashtead reported its H1 results on 9 December, deep into URI's Q4. At that
juncture, AHT increased capital expenditure guidance indicating markets
trading much as anticipated. Ashtead is favoured by only a fractional exposure
to Canada (first stepped into last year with a small acquisition) and lower
relative exposure to upstream oil and gas than URI. Structurally, AHT has
been taking share across its network and up and down in the market. Amongst
the broadly fixed universe of large accounts this implies a shift in share to AHT
with consequent losses elsewhere. AHT is due to report its Q3 on 1 March. At
this juncture the cloud of URI will likely put pressure on the share price. We
maintain our view of AHT's more favourable footprint, the positive backdrop of
US non-residential construction and structural grabbing market share through
consistent delivery of a service-led business model.

BE

So, nearly 7% down might be an overreaction.

11:16 am
BE

Or not. Dunno.

BE

Update We are updating our commodity price assumptions to reflect the current forward
curves ( 2016 30p gas / £34/MWh power). This results in a 19% cut to our 2016 adj. basic
EPS to 14.3p (14% below consensus 16.7p). Our target price is reduced to 175p
(previously 250p), which despite the 5.8% dividend yield, results in a prospective -10%
TSR – prompting us to downgrade the share from Hold to Sell.

11:21 am
BE

SG view We assume the 12p DPS (cut in February 2015) is held flat. We estimate the
improvement to the balance sheet capacity from the DPS cut and the one notch rating
downgrade has been eroded by lower commodity prices. We now forecast a 2016 payout
of 84% and an RCF credit metric of 29% (vs Moody’s target in the mid-20s). At our 175p
target price the shares would trade on a 2017 PE of 12x and DY of 6.9%, but we assume a
20% scrip participation, resulting in 1% pa dilution. In addition our forecasts do not
incorporate any material negative impact from the CMA Energy Market Review due in
March 2016 (a 1% reduction in the UK domestic supply margin = ca. 9% EPS dilution).

BE

How we value the stock Our target price is based upon a 175p divisional sum-of-theparts
analysis (see p. 10). For consistency our 2015 EPS forecast is stated before the
ca. 1p EPS adjustment for the Nuclear and Venture fair value depreciation. As we expect
year-end impairments to eliminate the majority of British Energy’s £800m balance sheet fair
value (NB: a 10% drop in medium-term power prices = a ca.£500m impairment vs the 25%
decline in the forward curve since 2014), this should minimise future fair value adjustments.

BE

Events, catalysts & risks to price target, rating & recommendation Centrica reports
2015 results on 18 February. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) is due to
provide its provisional decision on remedies in March. Upside risks: higher than assumed
commodity prices (see page 2) – eg a 5p/thm change in the gas price is equivalent to
ca.10% change in EPS; heightened power market tightness, reduced political risks and/or
lower upstream taxation.

11:22 am
BE

Centrica's July 2015 review was based on $70/oil and 50p gas holding flat through 2016.

BE

Turns out, not so much.

BE

In terms of whether it needs to raise, again ......

11:23 am
BE

Our reduced profit forecasts now suggest that the surplus balance sheet capacity we
previously expected (which could potentially have justified a restoration of the A-/A3 credit
rating by 2017) has been eroded in the short term – although longer term balance sheet
improvement could still be delivered through the group’s planned disposal programme.
Assuming net disposals of ca.£400m in 2016 (£600m wind-farm disposals less £180m of JV
debt already realised in 2015) and 20% scrip participation (at a cost of 1% pa EPS dilution),
we estimate headline RCF/net debt will improve from 18% in 2015 to 29% in 2016 – in line
with Moody’s targeted floor of mid twenties for Baa1 credit rating.
While we estimate this headline RCF metric should improve to 34% in 2017 we note that our
estimated RCF/net debt metric excluding the benefit of the £500m hybrid equity contribution
and assumed 20% scrip dividend participation increases in 2017 from 24% to just 25% - ie a large element of the headline RCF credit metric improvement is the assumed £400m
cumulative cash dividend saving estimated between 2015-2017.

11:33 am
BE

Or Argbury. Perhaps that's better.

BE

Clearly the only things that can save Home Retail (HOME) as an independent company now would be pressure on Sainsbury (JS) (SBRY LN, 236p, Neutral, FV 235p) management not to proceed to make an offer, or a derisory low-field price. For Sainsbury CEO Mike Coupe either would represent a significant personal blow and we would expect management to be even more determined to continue despite the almost universally negative response to his proposed strategy. The HOME team’s surprise move to sell Homebase to Wesfarmers of Australia does raise the question of whether the subsequently de-levered Argos rump could be taken private, which we examine in this note.
However, our main finding having done this work is that divisional profits as shown by HOME may have been boosted for Argos by re-allocation of Financial Services EBIT and that this undermines the overall valuation. Our FV rises to 135p from 95p.

BE

We have tested the various elements of Buy-Out arithmetic here. Private Equity could generate significant returns if the Argos Transformation Plan is successfully delivered in private ownership. But this is based in part at least on the starting point of very low profitability, which both highlights the risks involved for PE and limits the leverage a private vehicle could support initially and hence the exit price for HOME shareholders. Any consideration of the exit value of Argos must also be based on assuming that the Argos business model – which we believe has become more dependent on the contribution of consumer finance – is sustainable in private ownership (see below).

As part of this exercise we have also had a much closer look at the composition of profits as stated by HOME. We believe that the Financial Services (HFS) business achieves far greater profits than stated and that these are re-allocated to Argos (mainly) and Homebase. We have estimated that over half of current year Argos EBIT is in fact re-allocated HFS profits, suggesting that the erosion of product based profitability has been greater than investors would generally believe. (We have received no co-operation from HOME in our analysis which incorporates a number of assumptions which may limit the accuracy of our conclusions.) The implication here is that Argos needs the support of a consumer finance structure to sustain its operations.

11:34 am
BE

Having performed the analysis we feel that there is a bit less to HOME than meets the eye. While HOME management may be motivated to offer for Argos, we believe that the valuations of Argos and HFS have to be considered together by investors rather than assuming a separate valuation for HFS based on its debtor book, because the returns implicit in a separate valuation of HFS would effectively be double-counted as its profits are mainly shown currently within the Argos EBIT.

We assume that Sainsbury has probably done the same work we have managed in a couple of days over the last six months. So we would expect that it does not want to double-count assets either. This said the logic of its approach eludes us so its valuation is likely to as well.

BE

Canaccord also advising caution into the deadline.

PM

Hang on

11:35 am
PM

We assume that Sainsbury has probably done the same work we have managed in a couple of days over the last six months.

PM

That's a bit cheeky no?

PM

But go on

11:35 am
PM

Canaccord

BE

Similar conclusion, slightly more tame argument.

BE

With the clock ticking down to the 5pm deadline on 2 February (or potentially later if agreed by the Takeover Panel), by when J Sainsbury has to decide whether or not to make an increased bid for Home Retail, the answer should soon become clearer as to whether Argos is to continue with its Digital Transformation plan as an independent operator or (potentially) as a subsidiary of J Sainsbury. Home Retail is currently just over three years through its five-year plan, so it is a case of unfinished business at this stage.

This will, of course, be dependent on a number of factors. First and foremost is whether Sainsbury does return with an enhanced bid. Assuming it does, we must see at what level this is pitched and whether shareholders are willing to accept this. In turn, this may depend on the mix of cash and paper offered. Given Sainsbury's own travails and challenges in its core grocery market, we would assume that the higher the mix of cash over paper, the higher the chances of success in securing Home Retail's shareholders' agreement.

11:36 am
BE

The market is not privy to the level at which Sainsbury's rebuffed offer last November was pitched (although press speculation centres at around 130p). There have been three key events since then - the proposed sale of Homebase to Wesfarmers for £340m (c 42p per share); a further profit warning from Home Retail; and market weakness and volatility. These will all play a part in Sainsbury's thinking for what it views as both a "strategically compelling transaction" but also "not a must do deal".

As the potential bidder, it is only Sainsbury's (and its shareholders') view on the strategic compulsion of the transaction that matters. We do not have adequate insight into Sainsbury's strategy to comment in an informed manner, but it is clear from some of its published materials that the company (and its advisors) are serious in their deliberations and justifications on this matter. This has certainly changed our initial scepticism on the probability of a higher, follow-up approach.

BE

As long-term observers of Home Retail, we remain less convinced of the strategic logic and rationale of such a deal. However, just as beauty is in the eye of the beholder, value is in the eye of the bidder. Our analysis of the value of "rump" Home Retail, excluding Homebase at a £340m value, shows that any bid for the total group above 135p values this rump at a premium to the wider sector, compared with the 13% discount Wesfarmers has proposed to pay for Homebase. Only a "strategically compelling transaction" could justify that in our view.

BE

In light of our 10% forecast cuts following Home's Q3 IMS and some sector de-rating, in the absence of a bid approach we would have cut our fundamental valuation to 100p (from 115p). Ascribing a two in three chance to a bid at the current share price and a one in three chance of no further - or failed - bids, in which case fundamentals would re-apply, this gives our new target price of 134p. We therefore retain our SELL recommendation.

11:37 am
BE

All of which plays into the bear stuff above rather neatly.

BE

There's a quite startling disconnect between what the buyside says HOME is worth -- remember the flush of "we won't sell for less than 200p!" articles a while back -- and the value the sellside sees in the business.

BE

One can be cynical about both sides, of course. Though only the former is talking its book.

11:44 am
BE

OUR VIEW - low multiple but requiring proof of delivery and avoidance of multiple dilutive mix/outlook changes: The shares trade at ~10x 2015/16E (nil DPS yield), vs
Stagecoach at 10x PER (4.3% yield) and National Express at 13x (~4% yield), and Go-Ahead at 13x (4.2% yield). FirstGroup has a historical habit of meeting short-term
projections - often from better (but low multiple) rail profits as bus-related profits soften (for 2015/16E RBCe UK bus EBIT outlook had fallen 18% since Jan-2015 before
today). Even before the potential for multiple expansion if/when goals are delivered (which seems increasingly doubtful, in our view), the first step to deliver support for the
shares would come from delivering estimates without profit warnings (or 'moderated trading performance'), mix changes or later (year) cuts. So far, the record is not yet
consistent enough (in our view) and today sets that back further. So, theoretical significant upside exists if goals are delivered by 2018/19E, but we see the upside gains as
likely to be seen only on proof of delivery - while nil DPS means opportunity cost of waiting is not covered by income, while the wait looks increasingly risky.

BE

With regards to the TransPennine Express franchise, as discussed on the right ....

BE

... it's the usual problem of winning franchises. You get a load of upfront costs and not a lot of certainty on when they'll be earned back.

11:45 am
BE

RBC again.

BE

UK Rail wins - Capital is the sting in the tail of EPS lift: FirstGroup retained TPE contract with ambitious growth plans - but likely to see net cash outflow for the first two
years due to capex (not initially helpful rail dividend flow to parent company). The company is short-listed for Anglia (news due this summer). After TPE saw contingent
bonding at more than 60% of first year revenues, so we think the opportunity cost of contingent bonding will require industry players to strike more of a balancing act between EPS
uplift vs balance sheet capacity absorbed (and risk to dividends). This could mean future bids are more selective, or require a JV partner involvement for more capitalstretched
companies, e.g. for a SWT bid.

PM

The Tobacco industry is already highly consolidated (top four account for 70% of global
excl China volumes). However, recent press reports have suggested that number four
player Imperial Tobacco could be a consolidation candidate. Under our base assumptions,
we estimate that an acquisition of Imperial by a larger player would be accretive in both
EPS and value terms.

BE

Of the mega-caps, we prefer BAT to PMI, given a more attractive relative valuation and
more M&A optionality, in our view. We also like Imperial, as we believe the market is
too conservative on the growth outlook – with upside risk if it can rejuvenate Winston.

Source: Deutsche Bank
We re-examine our 2016 forecasts and find further potential downside: we cut
EPS by 5%. Our TP falls 19% to 770p. With risk of further weak trading in
college, low adoption year in school books and the possibility of a significant
round of restructuring in 2016, we retain our SELL.
We think problems are structural, plus partly cyclical
We think Pearson’s problems are structural, with cyclical pressures
exacerbating them. The challenges are most acute in US College (approx. 35%
profits) and where a reduction in margin to the level of the school business
would negatively impact profits by 15%. Over time, we think the education
market is becoming more competitive, as the old print-based oligopolies are
challenged by free content and new entrants.
We examine the returns issue and find more risk
Pearson’s October trading statement blamed higher returns of unsold college
books. In this note, we examine the issue of returns and find risk of further
downside. Our new estimates are 7% below consensus.
Risks include acquisitions, return of cash
Risks to our bear case include potential acquisitions, which, although
uncertain, could be mid-single digit accretive to EPS. Other risks include a rise
in college enrollments, which could be driven by an increase in US
unemployment, or “free college” schemes.
Valuation: we cut TP, maintain SELL
Pearson is trading on 13x PE 2016E and 15x P/FCF, which could appear low
compared to peers, but Pearson is experiencing organic revenue decline and
has not grown more than 1% since 2010. We cut our TP to 770p from 950p.
Our TP is based on an average of PE and EV/EBITDA versus peers and DCF
(8.5% WACC, terminal growth 1.1%, a weighted average of TG rates at North
America, Core and Growth segments).
